data.title: The Best Movies With Kill In The Title
data.meta_description: Over 100 filmgoers have voted on the 70+ films on Best Movies With Kill In The Title. Current Top 3: Licence to Kill, To Kill a Mockingbird, Kill Bill Volume ...
data.text:
Ranked By

695 votes

149 voters

Voting Rules

Vote up your favorite movie with kill in the name.

Latest additions: Kill

Most divisive: Kill the Irishman

Over 100 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The Best Movies With Kill In The Title

Have you ever noticed how many movies there are with kill in the name? This list ranks the best movies with kill in the title, regardless of genre or rating. What is your favorite movie with kill in the name? This is kind of an odd way to categorize movies, but that's also why it's so fun! There are probably one or two movies with kill in the title that you instantly think of, but you might be surprised how many others there are too as you scroll through this list.

This ranked poll of films with kill in the title includes movies like Kill Bill Volume 1, To Kill a Mockingbird, and Kill Bill Volume 2. Don't forget that this list is interactive, meaning you can vote the film names up or down depending on much you liked each movie that has the word kill in it.

Timothy Dalton, Carey Lowell, Robert Davi

This action-packed film follows the adventures of James Bond, played by Timothy Dalton, as he seeks revenge against a powerful drug lord who tortured his best friend and left him for dead. With Bond's traditional gadgets and cars, the movie contains numerous thrilling chase scenes and stunts. As the second and last film to feature Dalton as the iconic British spy, it remains a standout installment in the long-running franchise.

Released : 1989

Directed by : John Glen

Also ranks # 193 on The Best Movies Of The 1980s, Ranked

Also ranks # 31 on The Best Movies Of 1989, Ranked

Also ranks # 58 on The Most Rewatchable Action Movies

Based on the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Harper Lee, this American drama features Gregory Peck as small-town lawyer Atticus Finch, who defends a Black man accused of raping a white woman in the deep south during the Great Depression. The film is critically acclaimed for addressing issues of racism, class, and morality, with Peck's portrayal of the compassionate and principled Finch becoming one of cinema's most enduring characters. It won three Academy Awards, including Best Actor for Peck and Best Adapted Screenplay.

Released : 1962

Directed by : Robert Mulligan

Also ranks # 1 on The Top 45+ Films Released In 1962

Also ranks # 353 on The Most Rewatchable Movies

Also ranks # 34 on The Most Utterly Depressing Movies Ever Made

Uma Thurman, Lucy Liu, Vivica A. Fox

Directed by Quentin Tarantino, this martial arts and revenge film stars Uma Thurman as The Bride, who seeks vengeance against the team of assassins who betrayed her and left her for dead on her wedding day. Featuring dynamic fight scenes, stylish visuals, and a memorable soundtrack, it has become a cult classic and an influential work in modern cinema. The film's cliffhanger ending left audiences eagerly anticipating its sequel, which continues The Bride's quest for retribution.

Released : 2003

Directed by : Quentin Tarantino

Dig Deeper Behind-The-Scenes Stories From The Making Of 'Kill Bill'

Also ranks # 247 on The Most Rewatchable Movies

Also ranks # 103 on The Best Movies Roger Ebert Gave Four Stars

Roger Moore's final outing as James Bond in this thrilling espionage film sees the iconic agent facing off against a psychopathic industrialist, played by Christopher Walken, who plans to cause a devastating earthquake in Silicon Valley. With its engaging blend of action, suspense, and humor, the film remains a fun and entertaining entry in the Bond canon. Its memorable title song, performed by Duran Duran, topped the charts and remains one of the most popular Bond themes.

Released : 1985

Directed by : John Glen

Also ranks # 191 on The Best Movies Of The 1980s, Ranked

Also ranks # 25 on The 90+ Best Movies Of 1985, Ranked

Also ranks # 79 on The Greatest Movie Themes

Basil Rathbone, Nigel Bruce, Patricia Morison

This classic film noir showcases the partnership of Sherlock Holmes, portrayed by Basil Rathbone, and Dr. John Watson, played by Nigel Bruce, as they attempt to uncover a mysterious murder in London. Its intriguing plot, atmospheric cinematography, and strong performances from its central duo make it a highlight among 1940s detective movies. Notably, it was the last of 14 films featuring Rathbone and Bruce in their iconic roles.

Released : 1946

Directed by : Roy William Neill

Also ranks # 21 on The 40+ Best Mystery Movies On Prime Video

Also ranks # 49 on The Most Intriguing Mystery Movies Based on Novels

Also ranks # 95 on The 300+ Best Movies of 1946

Picking up where its predecessor left off, Quentin Tarantino's explosive sequel continues the vengeful journey of Uma Thurman's The Bride as she confronts her remaining enemies, including her former lover and boss, Bill. The film deepens its characters' backstories and expands on the brilliantly choreographed action scenes that made the first installment a hit. Overall, it serves as a fitting and satisfying conclusion to the two-part saga.

Released : 2004

Directed by : Quentin Tarantino

Also ranks # 361 on The Most Rewatchable Movies

Also ranks # 164 on The Best Movies Roger Ebert Gave Four Stars

Also ranks # 23 on The Best Movie Sequels Ever Made
